Key Arguments: The bill is seen as an attempt to stifle free speech and dissent against the current government's policies.
It is perceived as a tool to enforce a 'woke' and anti-Christian agenda.
The bill is compared to totalitarian regimes and is seen as a slippery slope towards tyranny.
The bill is believed to give excessive power to the Australian Communications and Media Authority (ACMA), which could lead to censorship.
The bill is viewed as a violation of international human rights obligations, particularly concerning freedom of speech and thought.
Notable Quotes: The power to decide which speech constitutes ‘misinformation’ and must be censored is, at heart, totalitarian.
This Bill is a totalitarian government’s attempt to thwart and prevent freedom of speech, freedom of religious belief, freedom of conscience and freedom of action.

The passage of the Communications Legislation Amendment (Combatting Misinformation and Disinformation) Bill 2023 would put the Commonwealth of Australia in breach of its international human rights obligations.
